channel.title: BBC News - World

item.title: Aukus pact: France and US seek to mend rift
item.description: The deal caused outrage in France, which lost a contract to build submarines for Australia.

item.title: Angry scenes at Haiti airport as deported migrants arrive
item.description: The US is flying migrants out of a Texas border town where 13,000 have gathered in makeshift camps.

item.title: Angela Merkel: What will Germans miss about the chancellor?
item.description: BBC Europe editor Katya Adler takes a road trip to find out how Germans will remember their chancellor.

item.title: 'Side-eying Chloe' Clem to sell iconic meme as NFT
item.description: The image of Chloe Clem could fetch her tens of thousands of dollars at auction.

item.title: Air pollution: Even worse than we thought - WHO
item.description: The WHO is slashing recommended maximum limits of key pollutants as evidence of danger mounts.

item.title: The edible insects coming to a supermarket near you
item.description: A number of firms are now farming locusts and mealworms for human consumption.

item.title: Melbourne earthquake: Australians react to rare quake that rattled country
item.description: One resident thought the 5.9 magnitude quake was just his neighbours doing an intense workout.

item.title: Humanity reaching a turning point on climate - UK PM
item.description: World leaders must make major changes in four areas - "coal, cars, cash and trees", Boris Johnson says.

item.title: US approves Covid booster jabs for some older and at-risk Americans
item.description: The move applies to Americans over 65 who were vaccinated with Pfizer, and those at high Covid risk.

item.title: Extremists using video-game chats to spread hate
item.description: Campaigners say including extremist narratives among everyday conversations can be a pathway to radicalisation.

item.title: Taiwan seeks entry into key trade pact before China
item.description: Taiwan has warned that its application into the CPTPP could be affected should China join first.

item.title: Cavers descend into Yemen's 'Well of Hell' for first time
item.description: The 112m-deep pit has long been shunned by many local people, who believe it harbours genies.

item.title: Grim echoes of history in images of Haitians at US-Mexico border
item.description: Pictures of border officers rounding up black men have drawn comparisons to US slave patrols.

item.title: Afghanistan's female volleyball players tell of threats and fear
item.description: Afghan female volleyball players tell the BBC that one of the squad was killed last month.

item.title: Changing China: Why Xi Jinping is leading a way back to socialism
item.description: China has not been very socialist for years, but the Communist Party looks set to change that.

item.title: Angela Merkel: Four expert verdicts on a contested legacy
item.description: When the German chancellor steps down, how will history remember her? Four experts have their say.

item.title: Gabby Petito and Brian Laundrie: What do we know about the boyfriend?
item.description: A body found on Sunday is that of Gabby Petito, but her fiancÃ© remains missing. This is what we know.

item.title: Bolsonaro: Fact-checking claims by the Brazilian leader at UN
item.description: Mr Bolsonaro's speech to the UN had a number of claims in it, which we've looked into.

item.title: Central African Republic war: No-go zones and Russian meddling
item.description: All sides are accused of planting landmines in a dangerous shift in the Central African Republic.

item.title: Life at 50C: Heat hitting home in Australia
item.description: Cities like Sydney are already experiencing extremely hot days because of climate change.

item.title: Melbourne protests: Third day of violent anti-vaccine demonstrations
item.description: Demonstrators have been marching against lockdowns and mandatory vaccines in Australia's second largest city.

item.title: BTS: Korean boyband open UN general debate with performance and speech
item.description: The UN general debate opened with K-pop band BTS, followed by a speech about sustainable development.

item.title: Imran Khan: Afghan women 'are very strong'
item.description: Pakistan's prime minster suggests that, in time, women can "assert their rights" under the Taliban.

item.title: A year in Calais: One migrantâs year-long attempt to cross the Channel
item.description: The BBC followed Iranian migrant Alex, as he tried to cross from France to the UK with a smuggler.
